task.title: Installing the DITA Toolkit
task.shortdesc: This topic explains how to install the DITA Toolkit processing environment.

prereq.p: The recommended use of the DITA Toolkit components is inside of the Java environment because its pre-process architecture needs Java and Java-based tools. Therefore, before installing the DITA Toolkit processing environment, ensure that you have installed the following prerequisite tools :See Tested platforms and tools for detailed information about versions of these tools that have been successfully tested with the current toolkit release.

dlentry.dd:
Provides the basic environment for most tools used in this toolkit.
You can download and install the Java Development Kit (JDK) 1.4.2 (available on) into a directory of your choice.

Provides the main transformation services via the advanced XSLT processor Saxon 6.5 or Xalan-J 2.6 in the toolkit.
You can download and extract the Saxon 6.5 (available on ) or the Xalan-J 2.6(available on ) file into a directory of your choice.
Provides the standard setup and sequencing of processing steps.

p.b: The following steps guide you to set up the DITA Toolkit processing environment.

step.cmd: Download the DITA Toolkit package file from SourceForge .

ul.li: It is recommended to download the latest version of the DITA Toolkit for stable usage.
If you use Linux, click here to continue the setting up process.

step.cmd: Extract the package file into a directory of your choice.
Set up your environment variable JAVA_HOME to your installation directory for JDK or JRE.

ul.li:
Set up ANT_OPTS.
set ANT_OPTS=%ANT_OPTS% -Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=com.icl.saxon.TransformerFactoryImplif you do not use Saxon, please remove the saxon.jar file and ANT_OPTS from the environment variable.

Set up CLASSPATH to include the xalan.jar file and the xercesImpl.jar file. set CLASSPATH=%CLASSPATH%;<xalan_dir>\binif you don't use the Xalan, please remove jar files related to the Xalan from the environment variable CLASSPATH.

step.cmd: If you need to build compiled JavaHelp, PDF output and compiled HTML Help, you should install some build tools for these formats of outputs

info.p: JavaHelp is free software that can build online help for operating systems, applications, and devices. If you have set up JavaHelp, the DITA Open Toolkit can build online Java help by invoking JavaHelp software. To download and install JavaHelp software, go to

FOP (Formatting Objects Processor) is a Java application and is the print formatter driven by XSL formatting objects (XSL-FO). FOP reads a formatting object tree and transforms the object to PDF output. If you have set up FOP, the DITA Open Toolkit can build PDF output by invoking FOP. To download and install the binary distribution for FOP, go to

Microsoft HTML Help Workshop is a program designed to create and compile .CHM help files using HTML source files. If you have set up Microsoft HTML Help Workshop, the DITA Open Toolkit can build .CHM help files by invoking the Workshop. To download and install Microsoft HTML Help Workshop, go to
If you have installed one or more of these optional build tools, you should choose the following options to set up.

chrow.choption: If you have installed the JavaHelp,
chrow.chdesc:
set up the environment variable JHHOME to your installation directory for JavaHelp. For example:
set JHHOME=<javahelp_dir>

chrow.choption: If you have installed the FOP,
chrow.chdesc:
set up your environment variable CLASSPATH to include the fop.jar, batik.jar and avalon.jar files in the FOP directory. For example:
set CLASSPATH=%CLASSPATH%;<fop_dir>\build;<fop_dir>\lib

chrow.choption: If you want to build HTML Help output,
chrow.chdesc: install Microsoft HTML Help Workshop to the default directory.

step.cmd: Test the DITA Toolkit when you complete above steps.

stepxmp.p: You can do the following steps under the command prompt to test whether the DITA Toolkit and the XSLT engine are successfully installed.

li.p: Run all demo in the DITA Toolkit directory.
Or you can run specific file individually.

p.note: Input ant -projecthelp to see the list of tasks

note.b: If you can pass this test, it means that all of the tools are installed correctly.

task.title: Set up DITA Toolkit in Linux

shortdesc.b: The following steps guide you to set up the DITA Toolkit processing environment in Linux.

step.cmd: Extract the package file into a Linux home directory.

info.note: You can extract all package files and toolkits either to your private home directory for exclusive usage or to /usr/local/share/ directory for sharing.

step.cmd: Set up your environment variable JAVA_HOME.
Set up your environment variable PATH.
Set up your environment variable CLASSPATH

ul.li:
Set up CLASSPATH to include the saxon.jar file.
export CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:<saxon_dir>/saxon.jar

Set up ANT_OPTS.
export ANT_OPTS=$ANT_OPTS -Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=com.icl.saxon.TransformerFactoryImplif you don't use Saxon, please remove the saxon.jar file and ANT_OPTS from the environment variable.

Set up CLASSPATH to include the xalan.jar file and the xercesImpl.jar file.
export CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:<xalan_dir>/binif you don't use the Xalan, please remove jar files related to the Xalan from the environment variable CLASSPATH.

step.cmd: If you have installed build tools for compiled JavaHelp, PDF output and compiled HTML Help, you should choose the following options to set up.

chrow.choption: If you have installed the JavaHelp,
chrow.chdesc:
set up the environment variable JHHOME to your installation directory for JavaHelp. For example:
export JHHOME=<javahelp_dir>

chrow.choption: If you have installed the FOP,
chrow.chdesc:
set up your environment variable CLASSPATH to include the fop.jar, batik.jar and avalon.jar files in the FOP directory. For example:
export CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:<fop_dir>/build:<fop_dir>/lib

chrow.choption: If you want to build HTML Help output,
chrow.chdesc: install Microsoft HTML Help Workshop to the default directory.

cmd.xref: Test the DITA Toolkit when you complete above steps.
